subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: ... Thinking specifically about the annotations nightly and bug , I would rather have those tests in separate source trees from the normal tests. I should
messageBody:
Bradley, Todd wrote:

> David Saff wrote:
> > First, I accomplish what you discuss through package
> > organization: I can run test.unit.**, test.online.**, or
> > test.** to get everything.
> > This doesn't match every conceivable need, but it does match
> > every need I've had so far. Would it handle your current situation?
>
> As Cedric pointed out, this only works if a test is a member of only one
> group. As so many others do, many of my tests are annotated to be in
> multiple groups. For instance, "nightly" and "quick" and "bug" meaning
> "I want CruiseControl to run this test every night. Also, this test is
> quick (and is therefore suitable for our continuous build). Finally,
> this test illustrates a bug which is not yet fixed."

Thinking specifically about the annotations "nightly" and "bug", I would
rather have those tests in separate source trees from the "normal"
tests. I should think that moving a test in and out of the nightly build
is not done several times per day, so an annotation is more flexible
than necessary. Same for tests that can't pass due to a bug in someone
else's code. (Of course, can't you just rewrite the test to pass now,
but fail when the bug is fixed? Works great for me and doesn't require
an annotation or anything: just a failure message like 'Somebody might
have fixed bug 12578. If so, change this assertion.')

So while annotations can solve these problems, they require building a
new, complex thing to use well, rather than relying on support that
already exists, and that perhaps helps me act more intentionally when
changing a test's "group".

I'm thrilled that TestNG already does this, but this is not the TestNG
mailing list.
